name: Brazil
introduction: Following more than three centuries under Portuguese rule Brazil gained its independence in 1822 maintaining a monarchical system of government until the abolition of slavery in 1888 and the subsequent proclamation of a republic by the military in 1889. Brazilian coffee exporters politically dominated the country until populist leader Getulio VARGAS rose to power in 1930. By far the largest and most populous country in South America Brazil underwent more than a half century of populist and military government until 1985 when the military regime peacefully ceded power to civilian rulers. Brazil continues to pursue industrial and agricultural growth and development of its interior. Having successfully weathered a period of global financial difficulty in the late 20th century Brazil was seen as one of the world’s strongest emerging markets and a contributor to global growth. The awarding of the 2014 FIFA World Cup and 2016 Summer Olympic Games the first ever to be held in South America was seen as symbolic of the country’s rise. However since about 2013 Brazil has been plagued by a shrinking economy growing unemployment and rising inflation. Political scandal resulted in the impeachment of President Dilma ROUSSEFF in May 2016 a conviction that was upheld by the Senate in August 2016; her vice president Michel TEMER will serve as president until 2018 completing her second term.
overview: Brazil a vast South American country stretches from the Amazon Basin in the north to vineyards and massive Iguaçu Falls in the south. Rio de Janeiro symbolized by its 38m Christ the Redeemer statue atop Mount Corcovado is famed for its busy Copacabana and Ipanema beaches as well as its enormous raucous Carnaval festival featuring parade floats flamboyant costumes and samba music and dance.

languages.area: Amazonas, Middle Vaupés River, Santa Rosa (Juquira), Iauarete, Periquitos, and Ji-Ponta. Also in Colombia.

languages.name: Tapirapé
languages.area: Northeast Mato Grosso, mouth of Tapirapé and Araguaia rivers.

languages.name: Aikanã
languages.area: Rondônia, west of Vilhena, near Cuiabá-Porto Velho highway.

languages.name: Tapeba
languages.area: Ceará River, Caucaia, Ceará.

languages.name: Ticuna
languages.area: West Amazonas. Also in Colombia, Peru.

languages.name: Tereno
languages.area: Mato Grosso do Sul. 20 villages and 2 cities.

languages.name: Tingui-Boto
languages.area: Alagoas.

languages.name: Truká
languages.area: Pernambuco, Bahía.

languages.name: Tukumanféd
languages.area: Rondônia, mouth of Cacoal tributary of the Jiparaná.

languages.name: Tremembé
languages.area: Almofa, la Ceará.

languages.name: Tupinikin
languages.area: Espirito Santo, Bahia.

languages.name: Tuparí
languages.area: Rondônia, Branco River, tributary of the Guaporé, Pororoca Post.

languages.name: Trumai
languages.area: Mato Grosso, Xingú Park, source of Xingú River, villages along banks.

languages.name: Tembé
languages.area: Maranhão and Gurupi rivers. In Gurupi about 100 of 170 speak Tembé.

languages.name: Trió
languages.area: South central, Tepoe and Alalapadu villages. Also in Brazil.

languages.name: Torá
languages.area: Amazonas, lower Rio Marmelos, tributary of Rio Madeira.

languages.name: Tuxá
languages.area: Bahía, Pernambuco.

languages.name: Tuyuca
languages.area: Inambu, Tiquie, and Papurí rivers. Also in Brazil.

languages.name: Tucano
languages.area: Amazonas. Wasonas primarily in Yacayacá village. Also in Colombia.

languages.name: Turkish
languages.area: Widespread in Turkey as L1 or L2. Also in Australia, Austria, Azerbaijan, Belgium, Bosnia and Herzegovina, Bulgaria, Canada, Cyprus, Denmark, Egypt, El Salvador, Finland, France, Georgia, Germany, Greece, Honduras, Iran, Iraq, Israel, Kazakhstan, Kyrgyzstan, Macedonia, Netherlands, Romania, Russian Federation (Asia), Serbia, Sweden, Switzerland, Tajikistan, Ukraine, United Arab Emirates, United Kingdom, United States, Uzbekistan.

languages.name: Tuxináwa
languages.area: Acre.

languages.name: Turiwára
languages.area: Pará, with the Tembé on Acará-miri River.

languages.name: Ikpeng
languages.area: Mato Grosso, Xingú Park.

languages.name: Kayapó
languages.area: Mato Grosso, Xingú Park, south Pará, both sides of the Xingú River, west up to the Iriri and tributaries, and west bank to the Fresco and Zinho rivers. 14 villages.

languages.name: Uamué
languages.area: Pernambuco, vicinity of Floresta.

languages.name: Ukrainian
languages.area: Also in Argentina, Armenia, Azerbaijan, Belarus, Brazil, Canada, Croatia, Czech Republic, Estonia, Georgia, Hungary, Kazakhstan, Kyrgyzstan, Latvia, Lithuania, Moldova, Paraguay, Poland, Romania, Russian Federation (Asia), Serbia, Slovakia, Tajikistan, Turkmenistan, United States, Uzbekistan.

languages.name: Urubú-Kaapor Sign Language
languages.area: Maranhão.

languages.name: Umotína
languages.area: Mato Grosso, along Paraguay River.

languages.name: Enawené-Nawé
languages.area: Northwestern Mato Grosso.

languages.name: Urubú-Kaapor
languages.area: Maranhão, Gurupi River. 8 to 10 villages scattered over 2,800 sq. mi.

languages.name: Uru-Pa-In
languages.area: Rondônia, Ariquemes Municipality.

languages.name: Urumi
languages.area: Rondônia, Marmelos River, tributary of the middle Madeira.

languages.name: Uru-Eu-Wau-Wau
languages.area: Rondônia, on upper Jaciparaná, Cautário, and Jamari rivers.

languages.name: Venetian
languages.area: North, Venice, Tre Venezie area; Venezia Eugànea west to Verona, south to the Po, east to the border of the Fruili; Trentino-Alto Adige (Suedtirol); Venezia Giulia, east of the Friuli including Trieste. Bisiacco is in Gorizia Province. Also in Brazil, Croatia, Slovenia.

languages.name: Kamakan
languages.area: Bahia area.

languages.name: Wakoná
languages.area: Alagoas.

languages.name: Wapishana
languages.area: Southwest Guyana, south of the Kanuku Mountains, northwest of the Waiwai; a few villages. Also in Brazil.

languages.name: Waurá
languages.area: Mato Grosso, Xingú Park.

languages.name: Waiwai
languages.area: Amazonas, Pará, Roraima. Also in Guyana.

languages.name: Wayana
languages.area: Southeast Suriname villages. Also in Brazil, French Guiana.

languages.name: Yanomámi
languages.area: Roraima, Waicá post, Uraricuera River; Amazonas, Toototobi post; Roraima, Catrimani River.

languages.name: Wiraféd
languages.area: Rondônia, on Riosinho and Muquí tributaries of the Jiparaná.

languages.name: Mamaindé
languages.area: Mato Grosso, between Cabixi and Pardo rivers.

languages.name: Wasu
languages.area: Alagoas.

languages.name: Wayoró
languages.area: Rondônia, Pororoca Post, Guapore River.

languages.name: Kaimbé
languages.area: Bahía.

languages.name: Katawixi
languages.area: Amazonas.

languages.name: Xavánte
languages.area: Mato Grosso. 6 noncontiguous reservations, 80 villages.

languages.name: Kambiwá
languages.area: Pernambuco.

languages.name: Xerénte
languages.area: Tocantins, between Rio do Sono and Rio Tocantins.

languages.name: Xetá
languages.area: Paraná, among Kaingang [kgp].

languages.name: Xiriâna
languages.area: Amazonas, Demeni and Rio Negro tributaries, near Venezuela border.

languages.name: Xipaya
languages.area: Pará, lower Xingú River.

languages.name: Xakriabá
languages.area: Minas Gerais.

languages.name: Morerebi
languages.area: Amazonas, Rio Preto and Marmelos. 2 villages.

languages.name: Xokleng
languages.area: Santa Catarina, along tributary of Itajaí River.

languages.name: Xukurú
languages.area: Pernambuco, Serra de Urubá (Arobá) near Cimbres City, Bahía.

languages.name: Korubo
languages.area: Amazonas.

languages.name: Kulina Pano
languages.area: West Brazil Vale do Javari Indigenous Territory, Curuça River, Aldeia Pedro Lopes village. Migrating to Tabatinga town near where Javari River meets the Amazon.

languages.name: Kapinawá
languages.area: Pernambuco.

languages.name: Krahô
languages.area: Maranhão, southeastern Pará, Tocantins. 5 villages.

languages.name: Kreye
languages.area: Maranhão and Pará.

languages.name: Krikati-Timbira
languages.area: Southeast Pará, Maranhão, Tocantins; Municipality of Amarante, Governador village.

languages.name: Sanumá
languages.area: Caura and Ervato-Ventuari rivers. Also in Brazil.

languages.name: Tawandê
languages.area: Rondonia, Pyrineus de Souza village, near Vilhena town.

languages.name: Kwaza
languages.area: Rondônia, west of Vilhena, near Cuiabá-Porto Velho highway, same reserve as Aikanãs [tba] and Latundês [ltn].

languages.name: Yaminahua
languages.area: Yuruá, Mapuya, and Mishagua. Also in Bolivia, Brazil.

languages.name: Yuhup
languages.area: Amazonas, Vaupés River tributary. Also in Colombia.

languages.name: Yawalapití
languages.area: Mato Grosso, Xingú Park.

languages.name: Yabaâna
languages.area: Amazonas, headwaters of the Marauia and Cauaboris, tributaries of the left bank of Rio Negro.

languages.name: Nhengatu
languages.area: Amazonas, Lower Vaupés, Içana, and Negro River areas. Also in Colombia, Venezuela.

languages.name: Yurutí
languages.area: Upper Pacá River (tributary of Papurí), Caño Yi River (tributary of the Vaupes), and Caño Tuy River (tributary of the Vaupés). Also in Brazil.

languages.name: Yawanawa
languages.area: Acre.

languages.name: São Paulo Kaingáng
languages.area: São Paulo.
